topic.title: Using the with a GitHub Repository

body.p: includes a GitHub plugin that allows you to use the to edit files stored in a GitHub repository. The procedure in this topic assumes that this plugin is enabled in your installation of .
To open a file stored in a GitHub repository, use the dedicated GitHub Open Action button in the Open file section of the main dashboard.

To commit a file to a GitHub repository, select the Commit on GitHub action. A dialog box will open that allows you to enter a commit message and displays the branch on which the commit will be processed (you can also edit the name of the branch in this dialog box).
If you committed on the same branch as the currently opened document or on a new branch, and no conflicts were found, the operation is processed.
If you commit on an existing branch that is different from branch of the currently opened documents or when someone else has committed the same file, and a conflict is detected, a confirmation dialog box will appear. Commit Status Dialog Box
The Commit Status dialog box allows you to choose the following options:
You can click the link at the top of the dialog box to see the difference between the two commits.
Commit on a fresh branch - Creates a new branch that contains your version of the document so that you can merge the changes at a later time, after the conflicts have been solved.
Commit anyway - Commits the changes regardless of whether or not there was a conflict.
Cancel - Cancels the operation and your changes are not committed to the repository.
